texts.definition: The event of losing the abilities of performing certain actions in a game.
markups: <style="Definition">The event of losing the abilities of performing certain actions in a game.</style>

Games do not have to let players have the same possibility of actions the whole game. This can be done by removing abilities during gameplay. Such <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> may be penalties for failing goals, the effect of enemy actions, the lack of resources, but may also simply be due to different play modes available at different times during the gameplay.

Respawning in multiplayer <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> is typically done without any weapons, and the special abilities they provided, gained in earlier gameplay. Dying in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eve%20Online">Eve Online</link></style> can have similar effects if one does not have up-to-date clones in that one loses experience points which can translate into skill losses.

Game masters in Tabletop Roleplaying Games such as Dungeons & Dragons or GURPS can sometimes be forced to invent events that are unavoidable to the players to strip them of equipment that disrupts the game balance. Temporary Ability Losses are however much more common due to combat effects, e.g. being frozen, paralysis, blinded, or knocked unconscious. When done as actions by players or enemies, these effect are called debuffs in World of Warcraft (as is effects that lessen the effectiveness of enemies).

Disasters and attacks by enemies in Space Alert can destroy various components of the ship, which effectively creates Ability Losses since the actions they provide can no longer be done. Being exposed to high levels of ultraviolet radiation in Ursuppe can force players to have to discard gene cards and the abilities they provide; similar Ability Losses can be caused to rockets by solar flares in High Frontier. Taking damage in RoboRally does not make actions impossible, but lock what actions one has to do in particular phases.

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> consists of deciding what actions are lost and what the reason for these losses are. While one reason for <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> can simply be to give <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> for failing goals, <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> may also be the natural closing effect of <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> can be temporary due to running out of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Energy">Energy</link></style> needed to activate them, but this becomes permanent <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> if the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Energy">Energy</link></style> used is a <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resource</link></style>. Other common causes for <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style>,  which can be seen as specific examples of how <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> can be <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, include <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> as part of <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> or being part of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Role%20Reversals">Role Reversals</link></style> where the losses of some <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> are usually countered by <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> in other <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>. Suffering the effects of a <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerability</link></style> is another cause for <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style>. The <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> can be mitigated by having <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> or by giving players <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> within other <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> modulate <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> since the <style="CurrentLink">Ability Loss</style> may actual only become a loss if all <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> with the ability are removed from gameplay.

Specific causes for Ability Losses include Environmental Effects and Game Items. The may be Traps, e.g. cursed Game Items, but that these cause Ability Losses may also be known in advance so players can expose themselves to them as part of Trade-Offs or Risk/Reward choices. Another type of cause for Ability Losses is to create Cooldown periods for Abilities - this is simply combining an Ability Loss with a Time Limit after that Ability has been activated. In great enough amounts, Debuffs, Decreased Abilities, and Deterioration can effectively give Ability Losses. In games with Character Alignments, not following ones alignment can be the cause of Ability Losses. Diegetic Social Maintenance or Diegetic Social Norms can be used in a similar effect to penalize agents in Game Worlds that do not live up to social conventions with the people they have relationships with or share Factions with.

The creation of <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style> can be a consequence of combining <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> of aggressive <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style>, i.e. making the aggressive <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> possible everywhere but within the <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>.

In games with <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> may naturally occur as the outcome of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> with players in order to restore <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>. Although not popular, it can also be part of <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style> in order to provide <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> between different strategies.

Ability Losses are not commonly used to advance Narration Structures unless they are Ultra-Powerful Events, since players may see goals in resisting the loss, especially in games that support Save-Load Cycles. One reason for enforcing these types of Ability Losses in Predetermined Story Structures are when they are important parts of Abstract Player Construct or Character Development. When the losses are part of the game story, they do provide a form of Varied Gameplay, as players have to adjust to a Limited Set of Actions, which may be used to maintain Challenging Gameplay. Half-Life has this as it at one point strips players of their equipment and the Dead Money Expansion to Fallout: New Vegas does it through temporarily removing all equipment when the Expansion is played.

Selective <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> may be enforced by a game design as an alternative to <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>, for example, making it impossible to attack shopkeepers in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style> when it is possible to attack monsters or making it impossible to shoot allies in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%203">Doom 3</link></style>. This saves production costs in dealing with unwanted narrative developments, and can from the perspective of <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> as enforcing <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> but from the perspective of <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> as breaking <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> are common as <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, e.g. those caused by as the whole effects of <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> or those that are <style="Link"><link="critical-hits">Critical Hits</link></style> which cause <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> besides reducing <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>. Losing <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> naturally creates or restricts a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> for players and thereby players' their <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>. This most likely negatively affects any <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> players may have and can make it difficult to have an accurate <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style>. When <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> are temporary in the sense that they somehow can be regained, the pattern creates <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> goals.

The losses can be on an <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatar</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Unit</link></style> level or be applied on a player generally. <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> may cause <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> to be lost, but in the case of <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> possessed by <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> become <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> that only lead to losses of <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> when all of them are lost. This may however create <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> for others as they may be the only ones left competent. When <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> are related to <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, these loses can be seen as (negative) <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>; <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> can also modulate other <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, e.g. having some actions being taboo after having joined specific <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>. In extreme cases, <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> may cause players to have <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, which is equal to <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> if the loss is temporary and equal to <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> if it is permanent. However, <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> may reduce the complexity of a game while increasing the difficulty, thereby being able to modulate both <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>.

A loss of <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> can affect <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>. If the lost <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> were possessed by most or all other players or <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> this is a <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style>, but if the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> were <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, the losses can affirm <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> and be <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> if explicitly designed into the game. When <style="CurrentLink">Ability Losses</style> are combined with <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, this pair can be balanced in itself and require players to consider both the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> associated with losing one <style="Link"><link="abilities">Ability</link></style> to gain another.

<style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="character-alignments">Character Alignments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Debuffs">Debuffs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Maintenance">Diegetic Social Maintenance</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Role%20Reversals">Role Reversals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style>
